text:
The day cancer took me from anticipation to devastation -- and then we danced Updated: February 24, 2017 — 8:45 AM EST 311 Share Close icon Diagnosis: Cancer 
CT scan of the abdomen shows the patient to have multiple bilateral, too numerous to count, liver lesions consistent with widespread liver metastases.” 
My vision blurred. The world before my eyes spun and came to a standstill. Reeling, I fumbled for a bench outside near a sign which proclaimed, “There is Always Hope.” 
looking forward to the father- daughter school dance that evening. 
my planned immunotherapy clinical trial, but didn't worry about it. My disease — metastatic colon cancer — has been slow growing and predictable for five years. 

Some quite large. I knew what this meant. A much more aggressive disease in an essential organ – the type of situation that screamed, life-threatening. Near-term life threatening. 
My liver looked like Swiss cheese covered in large spots, including a few that were dangerously circling around my biliary duct. If they grew just a bit more and blocked that duct, an emergency stent operation would be needed. If that didn't work ... Game over. 
IV cancer. A world where you are constantly being scanned, each new scan a game of Russian roulette. This is why “scanxiety” is very real. My entire life changed with this single scan. 
Stop the clinical trial. Get on chemotherapy that very day. 


I was in that chemotherapy infusion room to save my life, get my liver ready for a future clinical trial and fight on. 

We had a great time.
